Identifying Characteristics: Brown shells, while others have olive-brown shells with decorative yellow markings
Coloration closely mimics that of the winter leaf of the tulip poplar
Yellow markings on their dark feet and face—some individuals have no yellow markings at all
Males have red irises and females have brown eyes
Feet are webbed only at the base—5 toes on each front leg normally 4 toes on each hind leg (although some individuals may possess 3 toes on each hind leg)
Able to close the plastron by pulling the hinged sections closely against the carapace—sealing the soft body in bone when in danger
Biology: Eggs are laid in June and July
Nesting occurs in the late afternoon
Females deposit eggs in a hole in loose or sandy soil and sometimes in lawns
Cavity is about 3 inches deep or about as long as the back legs of the adult female turtle
Hatching occurs in September or average incubation is around 87 to 89 days
Young either remain in the nest after hatching, emerge and go directly into hibernation, or emerge and explore for a few days to weeks, then hibernate
Young do not require food during their first summer or fall before going into hibernation
Diet: A large variety of foods-- earthworms, snails, slugs, grubs, beetles, caterpillars, grasses, fallen fruit, berries, mushrooms, flowers, bread, duck weed, carrion, birds, berries, insects, roots, flowers, eggs and amphibians—anything they can catch and fit in their mouths
Habitat: Deciduous or mixed forested regions—moderately moist forest floor that has good drainage
Bottomland forest is preferred over hillsides and ridges
Take 'baths' in shallow streams and ponds or puddles, and during hot periods may submerge in mud for days at a time
Often seen in open grasslands, pastures, or under fallen logs or in moist ground, usually moist leaves or wet dirt
Range: Eastern United States—from Maine to Florida
Also found in south to southern Florida and west to eastern Kansas, Oklahoma, and Texas
